{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} [[File:Potato_race_2.png|thumb|Riders in a mounted potato race. The rider on the white horse has just scored a point by placing a potato in his side's basket.]]
A '''potato race''' may refer to several similar [[racing]] events where contestants compete to collect a number of [[potato]]es as quickly as possible. Participants may be mounted on [[horseback]] or running on foot, depending on the style of race. Potato races of both types were most popular at community events such as [[county fair]]s, [[rodeo]]s, [[picnic]]s, and [[track and field]] meets from the middle of the 19th century until approximately the 1930s.
Mounted events were held in many locations across America, but were particularly prevalent in the [[American Southwest]]. Individual mounted events usually consisted of individuals competing to be the fastest at collecting potatoes along a structured course. Team-based events had no defined course, and were notable for their violence. Players were permitted almost every possible tactic for interfering with the opposing team, including dragging other riders off their horses.
Potato races, both on-foot and mounted, are occasionally still held at local gatherings or riding competitions today, although the violent mounted version has died out.
== History == It is unclear precisely where and when the potato race was originally developed. It was mentioned by name without elaboration in newspaper reports of athletic events in [[Scotland]], [[Australia]], and [[Wales]] as early as the 1860s.<ref name="CourierArgus">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20452415/1865_potato_race_scotland_article/|title=Presentation of prizes. Scotland's cup.|last=|first=|date=June 23, 1865|work=The Courier and Argus|access-date=May 28, 2018|location=Dundee, Scotland|page=4|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="TheAge">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20452795/1868_australia_potato_race/|title=The Cheswick Easter Sports|date=April 22, 1868|work=The Age|access-date=May 28, 2018|location=Melbourne, Australia|page=7|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="WesternMail">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20363878/cowbridge_grammar_school_athletic_sports/|title=Cowbridge Grammar School Athletic Sports|date=April 22, 1870 |work=Western Mail|access-date=May 25, 2018|location=Cardiff, Wales|page=3|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The [[state fair]] of [[Wisconsin]] advertised a potato race "that beats Base Ball all hollow" in 1869, although again there was no description of the rules.<ref name="WoodstockSentinel">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20363831/wisconsin_state_fair/|title=Wisconsin State Fair|date=August 26, 1869|work=The Woodstock Sentinel|access-date=May 25, 2018|location=Woodstock, Illinois|page=4|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In September 1871, newspapers in a number of American states reprinted a report from the [[Boston Advertiser]] which detailed an on-foot potato race that had taken place in [[Wilton, New Hampshire|East Wilton, New Hampshire]], with many remarking that such events were becoming fashionable.<ref name="BuffaloExpress">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20364191/1871_potato_race_buffalo/|title=A "Potato-Race" in New Hampshire.|last=|first=|date=September 9, 1871|work=Buffalo Express|access-date=May 25, 2018|location=Buffalo, New York|page=2|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="TiffinTribune">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20364223/1871_potato_race_ohio/|title=A Potato Race.|last=|first=|date=September 14, 1871|work=The Tiffin Tribune|access-date=May 25, 2018|location=Tiffin, Ohio|page=1|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="YorkvilleEnquirer">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20364276/1871_potato_race_south_carolina/|title=A "Potato-Race" in New Hampshire.|last=|first=|date=September 21, 1871|work=Yorkville Enquirer|access-date=May 25, 2018|page=4|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The county fair of [[Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]] listed an on-foot potato race on its program in September 1871, directly referencing these reports.<ref name="DailyLyncoming9th">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20362973/lycoming_county_fair/|title=Lycoming County Fair|last=|first=|date=September 9, 1871|work=Daily Lycoming Gazette and West Branch Bulletin|access-date=May 25, 2018|page=4|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="DailyLyncoming13th">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20363636/a_potato_race/|title=A "Potato Race."|last=|first=|date=September 13, 1871|work=Daily Lycoming Gazette and West Branch Bulletin|access-date=May 25, 2018|page=4|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Official rules for potato racing were printed in the 1902 Official Handbook of the [[Amateur Athletic Union|Amateur Athletic Union of the United States]].<ref name="OHAAUUS">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?redir_esc=y&id=DJ0uAQAAIAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=potato|title=Official Handbook of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States|publisher=American Sports Publishing Company|year=1902|isbn=|location=|pages=110|language=en}}</ref>
In 1902, ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' of [[Louisville, Kentucky]] described a mounted potato race that took place at the Louisville Horse Show, remarking on its violence and noting that it "made a big hit."<ref name="The CJ" /> It was not until 1912 that newspapers reported potato racing as a mounted rodeo event, with advertisements for one large [[Los Angeles]] rodeo listing the potato race by name, although without elaboration on the rules.<ref name="ArizonaStar">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20364673/potato_race_rodeo/|title=$10000 Prizes Offered For First Rodeo|last=|first=|date=February 13, 1912|work=Arizona Daily Star|access-date=May 25, 2018|location=Tuscon, Arizona|page=3|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> A 1913 report in the [[San Francisco Chronicle]] clearly describes a team-based potato race taking place at a [[Mardi Gras]] celebration in [[Salinas, California]], calling it a "new riding stunt".<ref name="SFChronicle">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20364768/potato_race_san_francisco/|title=Spirit of Mardi Gras in Control|last=|first=|date=August 3, 1913|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=May 25, 2018|page=35|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
By 1913, on-foot potato races were being referred to as old-fashioned.<ref name="Meader13">{{Cite book| url= https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page:Indoor_and_Outdoor_Gymnastic_Games.djvu/57| title=Indoor and Outdoor Gymnastic Games|last=Chesley|first=Albert Meader|publisher=American Sports Publishing Company|year=1913|isbn=|location=New York|pages=49|language=en|access-date=May 28, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|via=en.wikisource.org}}</ref> A 1917 article in [[Popular Mechanics]] magazine suggested racing to screw in a line of [[Lightbulb|lightbulbs]] as a substitute for potato races.<ref name="PopMech1917">{{Cite magazine| url=https://archive.org/stream/PopularMechanics1917/Popular_Mechanics_07_1917#page/n69/mode/2up/search/potato |title=Light Bulbs Supplant Potatoes in Odd Race| magazine=Popular Mechanics|last=|first=|date=July 1917|publisher=Popular Mechanics Company|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=21|language=en}}</ref> The popularity of mounted potato races as rodeo events died out by the 1930s.<ref name="Plains">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=hR7lrNLCi5sC&pg=PA126&dq=%22potato+race%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjh1re1lI_bAhUl6YMKHTf6B18Q6AEIRDAG#v=onepage&q=%22potato%20race%22&f=false|title=Plains Folk: A Commonplace of the Great Plains|last=Hoy|first=Jim|last2=Isern|first2=Tom|date=1987|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=|isbn=9780806120645|location=|pages=126–127|language=en}}</ref>
Informal on-foot potato races for children are still featured at many local celebrations and events in the United States.<ref name="Rhoten2014">{{cite news |last1=Rhoten |first1=Josh |title=You're Invited to Wyoming's Birthday Party |url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P2-36178379/you-re-invited-to-wyoming-s-birthday-party |accessdate=May 30, 2018 |work=Wyoming Tribune-Eagle |date=June 19, 2014 |location=Cheyenne, Wyoming |page=D1 |language=en|via=Questia}}</ref><ref name="Herald2011">{{cite news |title=Two-Day Planner |url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-268010758/two-day-planner |accessdate=May 30, 2018 |work=Daily Herald |date=September 25, 2011 |location=Arlington Heights, Illinois |page=2 |language=en |via=Questia}}</ref> Mounted potato races are still used as a part of [[Gymkhana (equestrian)|equestrian gymkhana]] events for youth today, albeit in a more structured and far less violent form.<ref name="EWS">{{Cite book|url=https://www.questia.com/read/117227349/encyclopedia-of-world-sport|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport|last=Levinson|first=David|last2=Christensen|first2=Karen|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1999|isbn=0-19-512778-1|location=New York|pages=182|via=Questia}}</ref>
== Foot races == [[File:Potato race on roof of Public School 44, New York City LCCN2016652411.tif|thumb|A potato race run on foot at a New York City school. ]] Potato races run on foot were commonly held for children as playground games and [[physical education]] in schools.<ref name="Playground">{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/playgroundbook00spergoog#page/n57/mode/2up|title=The Playground Book|author=Sperling|first=Sperling|publisher=The A. S. Barnes Company|year=1916|isbn=|location=New York and Chicago|page=47}}</ref><ref name="PhysEd">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=v_nhEzCw7pIC&q=%22potato+race%22+rake&dq=%22potato+race%22+rake&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3_ZSlpY_bAhUqyoMKHUj6D-sQ6AEILDAB|title=Physical Education for Elementary School|last=White|first=Monica R.|last2=Wild|first2=Doris E.|publisher=|year=1924|isbn=|location=|pages=103|language=en}}</ref> They were also featured at local events such as picnics or fairs, and still occasionally are today.<ref name="HawaiiGazette">{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=December 26, 1893|title=Founder's Day |work=The Hawaiian Gazette |location= Honolulu, Hawaii| volume= 28 | issue=52|url=https://evols.library.manoa.hawaii.edu/handle/10524/3844|language=en-US|page=5|via=eVols}}</ref><ref name="Rhoten2014" /> Potato races have also been used by researchers to measure physical performance in children.<ref name="Atkinson1925">{{Cite journal|last=Atkinson|first=R. K.|date=April 2–4, 1925|title=A Study of Athletic Ability of High School Girls|url=https://shapeamerica.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/23267224.1925.10651798?journalCode=uzjr20#.Wv7Xg2cks2x|journal=American Physical Education Review|volume=30|issue=7|pages=389|via=}}</ref><ref name="MillisBaker">{{Cite journal|last=Millis|first=R. M.|last2=Baker|first2=F. W.|last3=Ertugrul|first3=L.|last4=Douglas|first4=R. M.|last5=Sexcius|first5=L.|date=February 1994|title=Physical performance decrements in children with sickle cell anemia.|journal=Journal of the National Medical Association|volume=86|issue=2|pages=113–116|issn=0027-9684|pmc=2568164|pmid=8169985|via=}}</ref>
A number of lanes, one per runner, would be marked out. Potatoes would be placed at intervals along each lane, and a basket would be placed several feet behind the lane. Runners would race to retrieve potatoes one by one, returning each one to the basket before returning for the next. The winner was the first to collect all the potatoes in their lane.<ref name="Playground" /> In one variation, two runners competed to be the first to return fifty potatoes to their own basket, racing simultaneously to take the closest potato from a single line of one hundred potatoes rather than separate lanes.<ref name="Puzzles">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=QCy6DzgqcI4C&pg=PA100&dq=%22potato+race%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjomvfflI_bAhVMwYMKHRj-B6k4ChDoAQhLMAc#v=onepage&q=%22potato%20race%22&f=false|title=Mathematical Puzzles|last=Loyd|first=Sam|date=1959|publisher=Courier Corporation|year=|isbn=9780486204987|location=|pages=103|language=en}}</ref>
On-foot potato races have been likened to the [[Zuni]] game of ''A-we-wō-po-pa-ne,'' which involved collecting stones rather than potatoes.<ref name="Owens1891">{{Cite magazine|last=Owens|first=John G.|date=May 1891|title=Some Games of the Zuni|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Popular_Science_Monthly/Volume_39/May_1891/Some_Games_of_the_Zuni| pages=40–41|magazine=Popular Science Monthly|volume=39|via=en.wikisource.org}}</ref>
Writing in 1915, feminist theorist [[Charlotte Perkins Gilman]] described seeing a [[Film|moving picture]] of a potato race on ice, and remarked on the notable difference between the performance of men and women, which she attributed to women's restrictive clothing.<ref name="Perkins1915">{{Cite book|url=|title=The Dress of women : a critical introduction to the symbolism and sociology of clothing|last=Gilman|first=Charlotte Perkins|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=2002|isbn=0313312702|editor-last=Hill|editor-first=Michael R.|location=Westport, Connecticut|pages=33|oclc=70735344|orig-year=1915|editor-last2=Deegan|editor-first2=Mary Jo}}</ref>
== Mounted ==
=== Individual sport === Potato races with mounted participants were historically geared toward adult participation. They were prominent in the American Southwest.<ref name="PopMech1915">{{Cite magazine|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=td8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA704&dq=%22potato+race%22+invented&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjeq42zxJrbAhXhCTQIHd78Aq4Q6AEIPTAE#v=onepage&q=%22potato%20race%22%20invented&f=false|title=Potato Race is Fast Game When Played By Cowboys|magazine=Popular Mechanics|date=November 1915|publisher=Hearst Magazines|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=704|access-date=May 28, 2018|language=en}}</ref> In mounted races, competitors used sharpened stakes to spear potatoes and bring them from one end of a course to another. These races were timed, and the racer whose basket was heaviest at the end was the winner.<ref name="Plains" /> One less common variation bore some similarities to the [[blood sport]] of [[Goose pulling#United States|rooster pulling]], but used potatoes rather than partially-buried [[rooster]]s. A line of potatoes was spaced out along a course, and a rider would ride by at a [[Canter and gallop|loping pace]], leaning down from their horse and snatching the potatoes from the ground. Riders who failed to maintain speed, or missed a potato, would be disqualified. The fastest remaining rider was the winner.<ref name="Plains" />
Mounted potato races have been staged which feature participants riding on vehicles rather than horses. The ''[[British Almanac]]'' of 1897 mentions a bicycle-mounted potato race in an article describing bicycle gymkhana.<ref name="Almanac1897">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=YnI3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA330&dq=%22potato+race%22+britain&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjFuM3qgKDbAhVuIDQIHTPUAG0Q6AEINDAC#v=onepage&q=%22potato%20race%22&f=false|title=The British Almanac: Containing Astronomical, Official and Other Information Relating to the British Isles, the Dominions Oversea and Foreign Countries|last=|first=|date=1897|publisher=Stationers' Company|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=330|language=en}}</ref> A large picnic in [[Radford, Coventry|Radford]], England, in 1908 featured a bicycle potato race whose riders were young women. It was described at the time as a "splendid exhibition".<ref name="McGrory2002">{{Cite news|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-93421681/weekend-time-tunnel|title=Weekend: Time Tunnel|first=David |last=McGrory| work= Coventry Evening Telegraph |location= Coventry, England|date=October 26, 2002 |via=Questia |page=34| language=en|access-date=May 30, 2018}}</ref> In 1910, 5,000 spectators at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] watched a sort of reverse potato race where passengers in [[car]]s tried to throw potatoes from the vehicle into baskets placed along a track.<ref name="Kramer2009">{{Cite book|url=https://www.questia.com/read/122038774/indianapolis-motor-speedway-100-years-of-racing|title=Indianapolis Motor Speedway: 100 Years of Racing|year=2009|page=44|last=Kramer|first=Ralph|last2=Andretti|first2=Mario|via=Questia|language=en|access-date=May 30, 2018}}</ref> ''[[American Motorcyclist]]'' magazine reported that the First Annual Motorcycle Rodeo, held in 1970, featured a potato race with riders mounted on motorcycles.<ref name="Fee1970">{{Cite magazine|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=KvkDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA12&lpg=PA12&dq=%22potato+race%22+%22old+fashioned%22&source=bl&ots=GPnuLYWp5w&sig=R2Jww_qa-r0FA_bNCtb0tncaDWo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjHyb-at6nbAhWVLH0KHYl5AgI4ChDoAQg3MAM#v=onepage&q=%22potato%20race%22%20%22old%20fashioned%22&f=false|title=AMA Club Sponsors Motorcycle Rodeo|magazine=American Motorcyclist|last=Fee|first=Robert O.|date=October 1970|page=12|publisher=American Motorcyclist Association|language=en}}</ref>
=== Team-based tournament === {{Quote|text=Swinging their laths like swords and crashing into one another, potato racers at [[Cassoday, Kansas|Cassoday]] left the hundred-yard course strewn with potatoes and an occasional horseman as spirits, and tempers, rose.|sign=Jim Hoy| source= ''[[Plains Folk|Plains Folk: A Commonplace of the Great Plains]]'', p. 126<ref name="Plains" />}} [[File:Mounted potato race.png|thumb|279.981x279.981px|Riders engaging in a mounted potato race.]]
Around the turn of the 20th century some mounted potato races were run as competitions between teams attempting to fill a basket with potatoes. These events were not so much ordered races as they were free-for-alls, which could last as long as ten minutes.<ref name="The CJ">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20174032/potato_racing/|title=The Potato Race|last=|first=|date=October 3, 1902|work=The Courier-Journal|access-date=May 18, 2018|publication-place=Louisville, Kentucky|page=2|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> They were notably chaotic, as riders were not confined to lanes, and the rules permitted competitors to use their stakes to knock potatoes off the stakes of the other teams.<ref name="Plains" /> Physical violence often ensued; the [[autobiography]] of [[cowboy]] [[Henry Arthur Gant]] describes one team race at a [[Frontier Days (rodeo)|Frontier Days]] event in 1909 that became so violent that the judges were forced to halt the competition in the middle.<ref name="Gant2009">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=SyaC-lNC20IC&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139&dq=sharpened+lath&source=bl&ots=0ZfVS_Vr9C&sig=uHA1QfAAgFucDlIUTFGwmhButB8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjR7p6_oY_bAhXK7IMKHTX9DrYQ6AEIXTAM#v=onepage&q=potato&f=false|title=I Saw Them Ride Away|last=Gant|first=Harry Arthur|date=September 22, 2009|publisher=Castle Knob Publishing|year=|isbn=9781441402349|location=|pages=138|language=en}}</ref> ''The Courier-Journal'' noted that violent tactics such as pulling riders off their horses were considered acceptable, and that "biting is about the only thing that is barred."<ref name="The CJ" />
Writing in ''Plains Folk'', James Hoy remarked upon the similarity of these races to the [[Central Asia]]n sport of [[buzkashi]], which also involves fiercely competitive riders attempting to bring items to a goal, albeit on a much larger scale than potato races.<ref name="Plains" />
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Ridley Athletic Complex | nickname = | image = [[File:Ridley Athletic Complex.jpg|270px]] | location = 2221 W Cold Spring Ln, [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland|MD]] 21211 | coordinates = {{Coord|39|20|13|N|76|39|09|W|type:landmark_region:US-MD|display=it}} | broke_ground = 2006 | opened = March 13, 2010 | expanded = | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Loyola University Maryland|Loyola University]] | operator = Loyola University | surface = Sportexe Momentum synthetic turf | construction_cost = $62 million [[United States dollar|USD]] | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Loyola Greyhounds men's soccer]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2010–present)
[[Loyola Greyhounds men's lacrosse]] (NCAA) (2010-present)
[[Loyola Greyhounds|Loyola Greyhounds rugby]] (NCAA)
(2010-present) | seating_capacity = 6,000{{cite web |url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/facilities/locl-ridley.html|title=Reverend Harold Ridley, S.J., Athletic Complex|publisher=Loyola Greyhounds Athletics|accessdate=April 20, 2016}} }} '''The Rev. Harold Ridley, S.J. Intercollegiate Athletic Complex''' is a multi-sport facility owned and operated by [[Loyola University Maryland]]. It is located 1½ miles (2.41 kilometers) west of the main campus in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], on a {{convert|71|acre|ha|adj=on|lk=on}} parcel of land at the southwest corner of the intersection of the [[Jones Falls Expressway]] and [[Coldspring Lane]] in the [[Woodberry, Baltimore|Woodberry]] [[neighbourhood|neighborhood]].[http://www.loyola.edu/RidleyAthletic/about/ About the Ridley Athletic Complex]. Loyola University Maryland. At a total cost of US $62 million, it was the largest capital project in Loyola's history.{{cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/college/lacrosse/bal-sp.loyolalax13mar13,0,3315124.story|author=Van Valkenburg, Kevin|title=Loyola to open new lacrosse, soccer facility today|work=The Baltimore Sun|date=March 13, 2010}} Named after [[Harold Ridley (Jesuit)|Rev. Harold Ridley, S.J.]] at the request of an anonymous donor whose $5 million contribution was the most from an individual to the university,{{cite web|url=http://iggy.loyola.edu/catalogues/current/undergraduate/general/gifts.html|title=Gifts to Loyola University|work=Loyola Catalogues|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709015458/http://iggy.loyola.edu/catalogues/current/undergraduate/general/gifts.html|archivedate=2012-07-09|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-lacros/spec-rel/020110aaa.html|title=Loyola To Celebrate Ridley Athletic Complex Opening March 13|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date= February 1, 2010}} the complex consists of a 6,000-seat stadium for [[Loyola Greyhounds]] men's and women's [[association football|soccer]] and [[lacrosse]], an additional field for its men's [[rugby union]] club and eight courts for men's and women's [[tennis]]. ==Features== The centerpiece of the complex is [[J. Richard Awalt]] Field, named after the [[president]] of [[The Century Corporation]] who was a member of the Class of 1950 at Loyola College and a major factor in the facility's advancement.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyola.edu/commencement/08/honorees/carroll.html|title=Carroll Medal to J. Richard Awalt, '50|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Commencement 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100310180746/http://www.loyola.edu/commencement/08/honorees/carroll.html|archivedate=2010-03-10|df=}} A 6,000-seat double-decked [[grandstand]] running the length of the field is situated along one side. The two decks are separated by a promenade with [[concession stand|concession]] and merchandise stands, [[public toilet|public restroom]]s and stairs that connect both levels. Overlooking the seating areas are [[press box]]es and [[luxury box|luxury suite]]s. Eight sets of light standards, four on each side spread evenly apart, illuminate the stadium for nighttime events.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyola.edu/RidleyAthletic/progress/|title=Ridley Athletic Complex (construction updates)|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics}} A pair of video [[scoreboard]]s featuring [[light-emitting diode]] technology were installed by [[Daktronics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.daktronics.com/Company/NewsReleases/Pages/LoyolaCollege.aspx|title=Loyola's Intercollegiate Athletic Complex to Feature Daktronics Video and Scoring|publisher=Daktronics Inc.|date=August 5, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318002417/http://www.daktronics.com/Company/NewsReleases/Pages/LoyolaCollege.aspx|archivedate=March 18, 2012|df=}} The playing surface is [[Sportexe Momentum]] [[artificial turf]]. [[File:Ridley Athletic Complex.jpg|thumb|Loyola Maryland Greyhounds Lacrosse in the Patriot League Championships]] The auxiliary practice field immediately to the south is named the [[Sean Lugano]] Memorial Field, in memory of the 1995 Loyola graduate and one-time captain of the university's men's [[rugby union]] team who died in the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]] on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]. Lugano's family and friends raised over $1 million to name the field in his honor. It is the home of the [[Loyola Rugby Football Club]]. The playing surface is the same as the one at Awalt Field. The McClure Tennis Center, which consists of eight lighted courts, opened on April 11, 2015. Financed by a $3.2 million gift from an anonymous donor, it is named for Rick McClure, the university's men's and women's tennis coach since 1979 who had been inducted in Loyola's hall of fame in November 2003.[http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2014-09-25/sports/bal-loyola-maryland-announces-construction-of-tennis-center-in-honor-of-coach-rick-mcclure-20140925_1_new-tennis-facility-longtime-tennis-coach-patriot-league Lee, Edward. "Loyola Maryland announces construction of tennis center in honor of coach Rick McClure," ''The Baltimore Sun'', Thursday, September 25, 2014.][http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/c-tennis/recaps/041115aaa.html "Tennis Teams Split With Bison As Loyola Opens McClure Tennis Center," Loyola University Maryland Athletics, Saturday, April 11, 2015.] ==History== The idea for the athletic complex originated in a 1995 conversation between Ridley, Loyola's president at the time, and [[athletic director]] [[Joe Boylan]]. Land for the [[smart growth|smart-growth]] project was purchased in 1998, with {{convert|21|acre|ha}} previously owned by [[LifeBridge Health]] and the other 50 (20.23 ha) by the City.{{cite web|url=http://www.maacsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17400&ATCLID=3633953|title=Loyola to Host 2010 MAAC Soccer Championships at Rev. Harold Ridley, S.J. Intercollegiate Athletic Complex|publisher=Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference|date=December 16, 2008}} The project was stalled for years as the university faced opposition from Woodberry residents, mainly over environmental concerns since the parcel was once a [[landfill]]. Eventually the land underwent [[environmental remediation]] with the installation of [[geomembranes]] to prevent [[water pollution|groundwater contamination]] and a collection system that captured [[landfill gas|gases]] from leaking into the atmosphere. Additionally {{convert|29|acre|ha}} of the site were placed in forest [[conservation easement]]s.{{cite news|url=http://wbal.com/apps/news/templates/story.aspx?articleid=13288&zoneid=3|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120720112946/http://wbal.com/apps/news/templates/story.aspx?articleid=13288&zoneid=3|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 20, 2012|author=Jackson, Angela|title=Loyola College Announces New Stadium Completion Date|publisher=WBAL Radio|date=September 25, 2008}} [[Construction]] of the complex finally began in the spring of 2006. The opening event at the Ridley was a friendly match on March 10, 2010 between the [[Loyola Greyhounds men's soccer]] team and [[Crystal Palace Baltimore]] in a [[fundraiser]] to benefit [[Catholic Relief Services]]' [[2010 Haiti earthquake|Haitian earthquake]] recovery efforts.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-soccer/spec-rel/030210aab.html|title=Men's Soccer Hosts Crystal Palace In Charity Friendly|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=March 2, 2010}} The Greyhounds won 4–3.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-soccer/spec-rel/031010aaa.html|title=Men's Soccer Wins First Match At Ridley|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=March 10, 2010}} Its first intercollegiate contest there, a 3–1 loss to [[William & Mary Tribe|William & Mary]], was played six months later on September 7.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-soccer/recaps/090710aaa.html|title= William And Mary Downs Men's Soccer, 3–1|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=September 7, 2010}} Palace hosted a regular-season game that summer on August 18, a 2–0 defeat to the [[Rochester Rhinos]].{{cite news|url=http://www.palacebaltimore.com/home/457629.html|title=Rochester Defeats Palace Baltimore 2–0|publisher=Crystal Palace Baltimore|date=August 18, 2010}} The official [[grand opening|dedication ceremony]] for the whole complex was performed prior to the [[Loyola Greyhounds men's lacrosse|Loyola men's lacrosse]] home opener against [[Duke Blue Devils men's lacrosse|Duke University]] on March 13, 2010. [[List of mayors of Baltimore, Maryland|Mayor]] [[Stephanie Rawlings-Blake]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archbishop]] [[Edwin Frederick O'Brien|Edwin O'Brien]] and Loyola President [[Brian F. Linnane|Rev. Brian F. Linnane, S.J.]] led the celebration.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-lacros/spec-rel/031310aab.html|title=Greyhounds New Home Dedicated to Rev. Harold Ridley, S.J.|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=March 13, 2010}} The Greyhounds lost to the Blue Devils 8–5 in front of a sellout crowd.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-lacros/recaps/031310aab.html|title=Men's Lax Drops 8–5 Decision to Duke in Ridley Opener|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=March 13, 2010}} Women's sports premiered on March 16 with Loyola defeating [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights|Rutgers]] 18–6 in lacrosse.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/w-lacros/recaps/031610aaa.html|title=Loyola Wins Ridley Opener With Fast Start Against Rutgers|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=March 16, 2010}} The first contest at the facility for the Greyhounds' women's soccer squad resulted in a 3–2 victory over [[Towson Tigers|Towson]] on August 21.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/w-soccer/recaps/082110aaa.html|title=Schiro Scores Two In Women's Soccer Opening Win|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=August 21, 2010}} The Ridley was the site of the 2010 [[Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference]] Men's and Women's Soccer Championships. Between the host school's two teams, only the men qualified.{{cite news|url=http://www.maacsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=91123&SPID=11007&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=17400&ATCLID=205027267|title=Field Set for 2010 Chick-fil-A MAAC Men's Soccer Championship|work=MAAC Sports|date=November 10, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.maacsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=91127&SPID=11008&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=17400&ATCLID=205023768|title=Pairings Set for 2010 Chick-fil-A MAAC Women's Soccer Championship|work=MAAC Sports|date=November 3, 2010}} They lost to [[Saint Peter's College (New Jersey)|Saint Peter's College]] 2–1 in two overtime periods in the semifinals on November 12.{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-soccer/recaps/111210aaa.html|title=Saint Peter's Edges Men's Soccer in MAAC Semifinals|publisher=Loyola University Maryland Athletics|date=November 12, 2010}} Two days later, the Peacocks defeated [[Iona Gaels|Iona College]] 2–1 for the championship.{{cite news|url=http://www.maacsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&ATCLID=205030923&DB_OEM_ID=17400|title=Saint Peter's Wins 2010 Chick-fil-A MAAC Men's Soccer Championship|work=MAAC Sports|date= November 14, 2010}} [[Siena College]] won the women's title one week earlier on November 7 with a 1–0 overtime victory over [[Canisius College]].{{cite news|url=http://www.maacsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=91127&SPID=11008&DB_LANG=C&ATCLID=205026454&DB_OEM_ID=17400|title=Siena Wins 2010 MAAC Women's Soccer Title|work=MAAC Sports|date= November 7, 2010}} The Greyhounds men's lacrosse team had an 18–1 overall record en route to its first-ever national championship in 2012.[http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-lacros/recaps/052812aaa.html "NCAA CHAMPS! Loyola Wins First NCAA Lacrosse Title, 9–3, Over Terps," Loyola University Maryland Athletics, Monday, May 28, 2012.] Its only defeat was a 10–9 overtime decision to [[Johns Hopkins Blue Jays men's lacrosse|Johns Hopkins]] at the Ridley on [[Johns Hopkins–Loyola lacrosse rivalry|April 28]].[http://www.loyolagreyhounds.com/sports/m-lacros/recaps/042812aaa.html "Last Second Overtime Goal Lifts No. 10 Hopkins Over No. 1 Men's Lax," Loyola University Maryland Athletics, Saturday, April 28, 2012.] The [[Baltimore Bohemians]] played all of its home matches during the 2013 season at the Ridley.[http://www.uslsoccer.com/scripts/runisa.dll?M2:gp::72011+Elements/Display+E+47116+News/Display/+42834749+58149874+11397 "Bohemians Head To Loyola University," Baltimore Bohemians press release, Monday, January 28, 2013.] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.loyola.edu/ridleyathletic Ridley Athletic Complex – Loyola University Maryland.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050219123602/http://www.loyola.edu/swim/campus/admin.html Rev. Harold Ridley, S.J., President (profile) – Loyola College in Maryland Administrators.] * {{cite news|url=http://media.www.loyolagreyhound.com/media/storage/paper665/news/2005/01/25/Sports/Ridley.Leaves.Mark.On.Loyola.Sports-839777.shtml|author=Foy, Terry|title=Ridley leaves mark on Loyola sports|work=The Greyhound|publisher=Loyola College in Maryland|date=January 25, 2005}} {{Loyola College}} [[Category:Loyola Greyhounds]] [[Category:Sports venues in Baltimore]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Maryland]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in Maryland]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Maryland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in the United States]]

{{Motorsport venue |Name = Spokane County Raceway |Nicknames = |Time = [[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific]], UMT −8 |Location = [[Airway Heights, Washington]] |Coordinates = {{coord|47.660|-117.573|type:landmark_region:US|display=inline,title}} |Image = |Image_caption = |Address = |Capacity = |Owner = [[Spokane County, Washington|Spokane County]] |Operator = |Broke_ground = |Opened = 1974, {{Years or months ago|1974}} |Closed = |Construction_cost= |Architect = |Former_names = Spokane Raceway Park
(1974–2008) |Events = |Layout1 = [[Drag racing|Drag Strip]] |Surface = [[Concrete]] / [[Asphalt]] |Length_km = 0.40 |Length_mi = 0.25 |Turns = |Banking = |Record_time = |Record_driver = |Record_team = |Record_year = |Record_class = |layout2 = [[Road racing|Road Course]] |surface2 = Asphalt |length2_km = 3.7 |length2_mi = 2.3 |turns2 = |banking2 = |record_time2 = |record_driver2 = |record_team2 = |record_year2 = |record_class2 = |layout3 = [[Oval track racing|Oval Track]] |surface3 = Asphalt |length3_km = 0.80 |length3_mi = 0.50 |turns3 = |banking3 = |record_time3 = |record_driver3 = |record_team3 = |record_year3 = |record_class3 = }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Spokane Co.
Raceway |lat = 47.660 |long = -117.573 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 240 }} {{Location map |USA Washington |relief = 1 |label = Spokane Co.
Raceway |lat = 47.660 |long = -117.575 |caption = Location in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 240 }} '''Spokane County Raceway''' ("Spokane Raceway Park" until 2008) is multi-venue [[motorsport]] facility in the [[Western United States|western]] [[United States]], in [[Spokane County, Washington|Spokane County]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. Located northeast of [[Airway Heights, Washington|Airway Heights]] and west of the city of [[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]], it includes a quarter-mile (400 m) [[Drag racing|drag strip]], a {{convert|2.3|mi|sing=on}} [[Road racing|road course]], and a half-mile (800 m) [[Oval track racing|oval track]]. The raceway is currently a [[International Hot Rod Association|National Hot Rod Association]] (NHRA) member; it previously hosted [[National Hot Rod Association|International Hot Rod Association]] (IHRA) and [[American Hot Rod Association]] (AHRA) events. It is used as well for driving schools for marque-specific clubs, and has also hosted [[ICSCC]] (International Conference of Sports Car Clubs) championship events. The average [[elevation]] of the facility is approximately {{convert|2350|ft}} above [[sea level]]. ==History== The raceway opened {{Years or months ago|1974}} in 1974,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g7IRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ze0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4877%2C6376348 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Track's ready, so let 'em roar |last=Larrigan |first=Bob |date=May 31, 1974 |page=26}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DuQRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7uwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5247%2C1176377 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=It's 'Maple Leaf power!' |last=Larrigan |first=Bob |date=June 3, 1974 |page=16}} when investors produced more than two million dollars to build the facility.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gmhWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3PIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6514%2C5832148|newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Revised suit filed in track dispute |last=Morlin |first=Bill|date=August 18, 2004 |page=B3 }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XmdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5fIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2347%2C494384 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Angry investors gain legal win |last=Morlin |first=Bill |date=November 11, 2004 |page=B1 }}{{cite news|author=Morlin, Bill|url=http://www.spokesmanreview.com/local/story.asp?ID=14024|title=Losing Track|publisher=Spokesman Review|date=2004-07-04|accessdate=2007-11-18}} Questionable management resulted in a lawsuit against president and operator Orville Moe,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=upRXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yfIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5355%2C6009375 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Blocker |first=Kevin |title=Raceway Park owners sue |date=October 29, 2003 |page=B2 }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D7syAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HPMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6403%2C4475952 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Closure recommended for raceway |last=Morlin |first=Bill|date=December 13, 2005 |page=B1 }}{{cite news|last=Morlin |first=Bill|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C2hWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b_MDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6811%2C4868484|title=Raceway trustee files lawsuits |newspaper=Spokesman Review |location=Spokane, Washington |date=September 6, 2007 |page=B6}} and bankruptcy hearings.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WxdZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PPMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3886%2C2263720 |newspaper=Spokesman Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Morlin |first=Bill |title=Moe files for bankruptcy, avoids hearing |date=August 26, 2006 |page=B2}}{{cite court |url=http://www.waeb.uscourts.gov/HearingCalendar/PCW%2011-26-2007%20SPO.PDF |format=PDF |litigants=Spokane Raceway Park Inc. vs. Orville L. Moe |court=United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Washington}} Moe was eventually fired in June 2006.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pWlWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YfMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6811%2C6113691 |newspaper=Spokesman Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Morlin |first=Bill |title=Court asked to fire Moe, sell racetrack |date=March 18, 2006 |page=B6}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bmZWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LvMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4506%2C969550|newspaper=Spokesman Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Morlin |first=Bill |title=Moe fired as raceway manager |date=June 2, 2006 |page=A1}}{{cite web |url=http://www.competitionplus.com/2006_08/orville_moe.html |title=Banned from home? |accessdate=2007-11-18 |publisher=CompetitionPlus.com |author=Mark Klaas}} The track was sold as of April 10, 2008, purchased by the county,{{cite news |url=http://www.cheneyfreepress.com/story/2008/04/17/sports/looking-at-the-bigger-picture-of-spokane-countys-raceway-buy/3964.html |newspaper=Cheney Free Press |location=Washington |last=Delaney |first=Paul |title=Looking at the bigger picture of Spokane County's Raceway buy |date=April 17, 2008 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EORfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TPAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5692%2C3150644 |newspaper=Moscow-Pullman Daily News |location=Idaho-Washington |agency=Associated Press |title=Spokane County buys Raceway Park |date=June 27, 2008 |page=5A}} and renamed "Spokane County Raceway." The operator in 2009 was Bucky Austin of Austin Motorsports Management,{{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/jul/06/spokane-raceway-operator-vows-pay-bills/ |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Spokane raceway operator vows to pay bills |last=Camden |first=Jim |date=July 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}} which had a 25-year contract,{{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/may/08/emergency-crews-responding-spokane-raceway-park/ |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Prager |first=Mike |title=Driver strikes, kills pedestrian at Spokane County Raceway |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}} but was terminated after less than one year due to mismanagement.{{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/oct/29/spokane-county-expected-terminate-raceway-contract/ |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Spokane County fires racetrack operator |last=Camden |first=Jim |date=October 29, 2009 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}}{{cite magazine |url=http://www.inlander.com/spokane/money-pit/Content?oid=2132767 |magazine=Pacific Northwest Inlander |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Money pit |last=Walters |first=Daniel |date=August 25, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}} The track then was operated by Charlie Allen and Ron Hodgson; Allen had run the [[Wild Horse Motorsports Park|Firebird International Raceway]] in [[Arizona]] since 1983, and Hodgson was part owner of the [[Castrol Raceway]] in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]]. In February 2012, Allen was replaced by Spokane local Craig Smith, originally of [[Odessa, Washington|Odessa]], a one-time successful world champion dragster.{{cite news |url=http://www.inlander.com/spokane/another-lap/Content?oid=2137372|magazine=Pacific Northwest Inlander |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Another lap |last=Walters |first=Daniel |date=February 15, 2012 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.spokanecountyraceway.com/}} * [https://archive.is/20130415223141/http://www.spokanecounty.org/parks/MotorSportsPark/ Spokane County's official Motorsports Park site] (new) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120725134641/http://www.wmrra.org/ Washington Motorcycle Road Racing Association (WMMRA)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhA1HEyERA8 You Tube video] Spokane County Raceway - 2011 [[Category:Motorsport venues in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Spokane County, Washington]] [[Category:Sports venues in Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Spokane County, Washington]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] {{Autoracing-venue-stub}} {{Washington-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stambaugh Stadium | nickname = The Ice Castle | image = Stambaugh Stadium.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = West grandstand and press box | location = 577 Fifth Avenue
[[Youngstown, Ohio]] 44502 | coordinates = {{Coord|41.10946|-80.649298|type:landmark|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | broke_ground = | opened = {{Start date|1982|09|04}} | expanded = 1997 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Youngstown State University]] | operator = [[Youngstown State University]] | surface = SprinTurf | construction_cost = | architect = | general_contractor= | former_names = | tenants = [[Youngstown State Penguins]] (NCAA)
[[Youngstown State Penguins football|Football]] (1982–present)
Women's soccer (1996–2013) | seating_capacity = 20,630 (1997–present)
17,000 (1982–1997) }} '''Stambaugh Stadium''', officially '''Arnold D. Stambaugh Stadium''', is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Youngstown, Ohio]], United States, on the campus of [[Youngstown State University]]. The stadium was built in 1982, and is primarily used for [[American football]]. It is the home venue for the [[Youngstown State Penguins football]] team, a member of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) at the [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Division|Division I Football Championship Division]] (FCS) level and the [[Missouri Valley Football Conference]]. ==History== When it opened in 1982, Stambaugh had one large grandstand on the west side, with a seating capacity of approximately 17,000. During their time at Stambaugh, the football team has risen to become a power in FCS football, qualifying for [[NCAA Division I Football Championship]] playoffs 12 times, advancing to the championship game on six occasions, and winning four national championships through the 2015 season. The stadium is also known by fans as the "Ice Castle".{{cite web |title=Stambaugh Stadium |url=http://www.ysusports.com/information/facilities/stambaugh_stadium |year=2013 |work=YSUSports.com |publisher=[[Youngstown State University]] |accessdate=October 25, 2013}} The stadium's 25th Anniversary was celebrated during the 2007 season, and the top 25 players in the stadium's first 25 years were honored at a ceremony on September 15, 2007.Youngstown State University. [http://ysusports.com/fan_zone/traditions/top_25_players "Top 25 Players Represent Stadium's Storied 25-Year History"], YSUSports.com, Accessed March 4, 2011. Those players were: {{Div col}} :Tony Bowens (1987–90) :Adrian Brown (1996–99) :Pat Crummey (1998–2001) :Pat Danko (1988–91) :Harry Deligianis (1995–97) :Drew Gerber (1990–93) :LeVar Greene (1998–2001) :Matt Hogg (1994–97) :[[Tim Johnson (linebacker)|Tim Johnson]] (1999–2000) :Leon Jones (1992–95) :Todd Kollar (1994–97) :[[Paul McFadden]] (1980–83) :[[Marcus Mason]] (2005–06) :P.J. Mays (2000–02) :Dave Roberts (1989–92) :Jeff Ryan (1998–2001) :Ian Shirey (1996–99) :Dwyte Smiley (1996–99) :Randy Smith (1991–94) :Tamron Smith (1990–93) :Paul Soltis (1987–89) :Lester Weaver (1991–94) :Paris Wicks (1979–82) :[[Jeff Wilkins]] (1990–93) :Jim Zdelar (1987–88) {{div col end}} ===Renovations=== The stadium was upgraded and expanded prior to the 1997 athletic season with the addition of over 3,000 bleacher seats on the east side of the field, on the site of a practice field. In addition, a new press box was created and 14 additional luxury suites were built, along with a stadium club, which hosts the football team's weekly press conferences and is rented out for private events. Since 1997, the stadium's capacity is 20,630, making it the largest stadium in the [[Missouri Valley Football Conference]]. In the summer of 2009, an auxiliary scoreboard was constructed in the south end zone, giving Stambaugh Stadium a scoreboard in each end zone. New reserved chairback seats were also installed during the 2009 season along with two new flagpoles next to the scoreboard in the north end zone, one for the [[Flag of Ohio|Ohio flag]] and one for the United States flag. {|style="margin: 0 auto;" | [[Image:StambaughStadium1.jpg|thumb|250px|2008]] | [[Image:StambaughStadium2.jpg|thumb|250px|2008]] |} ==Other uses== In addition to hosting football and soccer home games, Stambaugh is also the home of YSU's athletic offices, football locker rooms and weight rooms, racquetball courts, ROTC offices, and visitor locker rooms. From 1996–2012, Stambaugh Stadium was also the home field for the YSU women's soccer team. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Youngstown State Penguins football navbox}} {{Youngstown State University}} {{Missouri Valley Football Conference venue navbox}} {{Ohio college football venues}} {{Youngstown}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Sports in Youngstown, Ohio]] [[Category:Youngstown State Penguins football]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Ohio]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Youngstown, Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1982]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Youngstown, Ohio]] [[Category:1982 establishments in Ohio]]

revision.text:
The '''United South of England Eleven''' (USEE) was an itinerant [[cricket]] team founded in November 1864 by [[Edgar Willsher]], as secretary, and [[John Lillywhite]], as treasurer.<ref>Birley, p.101.</ref> The USEE had no home venue as its prime purpose, like all similarly named teams of the time, was to operate as a travelling show and bring top-class cricket to places in Great Britain and Ireland which rarely received it. Fourteen USEE matches have been recognised by ''CricketArchive'' as [[first-class cricket|first-class]], mostly against the rival [[United North of England Eleven]] (UNEE). The USEE is estimated to have played 217 "odds" matches as a visiting team against local club sides which generally used 22 players.
The USEE was founded at a time of protracted antagonism between northern and southern professionals when the public's demand for exhibition matches was in decline. This was due to an excess of supply, as there had been several predecessors, and the growing interest in county cricket that was developing in the 1860s. But the USEE did succeed in prolonging its existence when it signed contracts with [[W. G. Grace]] and his brother [[Fred Grace|Fred]] in 1870.<ref>Birley, p.118.</ref>
For the next ten years, until Fred Grace's early death, the Grace brothers ran the USEE as its match organisers, for which they received payment, but they played for expenses only. Although the Graces were an expensive acquisition, they were cricket's main attraction and were guaranteed to draw large crowds wherever the USEE played. As a result, the USEE continued to prosper while the trend among its rival elevens was to fade from the scene. The USEE was the last of the major travelling elevens to fold, having seen a decline in public interest through its last three or four seasons. The travelling elevens lost out in the cricket market to county cricket which burgeoned during the 1870s, ironically because of the Graces' county [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]]. In addition, the public quickly warmed to international cricket which emerged at the end of the 1870s. The travelling elevens, which played largely meaningless matches against weak and unbalanced opposition, could not compete with the quality of top-class matches played by the county clubs against each other or a touring [[Australia national cricket team|Australian team]].
==Foundation== The USEE was created by [[Edgar Willsher]], as secretary, and [[John Lillywhite]], as treasurer in November 1864. It was part of the fall-out from a north-south schism within professional cricket which centred on bad relations between [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] and [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]]. The two counties played each other in July 1864 but then the northern professionals boycotted an [[All-England cricket teams|England]] v Surrey match and a [[North v South]] match later in the season. The southern professionals played in the North v South and won with embarrassing ease against makeshift opposition. Soon afterwards, they issued a statement that they would not honour the return match and this ended the fixture for some years. It was temporarily replaced by a match involving mostly southern players which was called North of the Thames v South of the Thames. In ''[[Scores and Biographies]]'', it was noted that "the United South was formed at first entirely from secessionists from the [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven|All England]] and [[United All-England Eleven]]s, principally the latter body". W. G. Grace commented that "after 1864 the All-England and United England Elevens were seen very little in the south".<ref>Rae, p.57.</ref>
The most significant event in the USEE's history was a match in August 1866 at [[John Walker's Ground]] against a [[Southgate Cricket Club|Southgate XV]] formed by [[V. E. Walker]] and his family. Southgate won the game by 3 wickets but, for the first time, the USEE team included [[W. G. Grace]], who scored 0 and 2.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/194/194690.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=Southgate XV v v UNEE XI, Southgate 1866 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> Also involved was [[E. M. Grace]] but he only ever played for the USEE a couple of times whereas W. G. and [[Fred Grace]] would in time become the team's mainstays.<ref>Rae, p.70.</ref>
After their father died in December 1871, W. G. and Fred Grace increased their involvement with the USEE to finance both their home (they still lived with their mother) and their medical studies. They received payment from USEE funds for organising matches and claimed expenses for travel and accommodation whenever they played. For example, when the team went to Scotland in 1872, the USEE was paid £100 by their hosts to cover the costs and £5 each went to the nine professionals in the team, leaving £55 (which in 2013 would be about £3,300) of which the lion's share would go to the Graces with perhaps £30 to W. G. and £15 to Fred (i.e., about £900 and £450 respectively per match in 2013 terms).<ref name=R103>Rae, p.103.</ref><ref name=W95>Williams, p.95.</ref> Since W. G. averaged ten USEE appearances per season through the 1870s, he was potentially receiving £10,000 per season in 2013 terms. This was not the end of it because he claimed appearance fees whenever he guested for another team, rightly adjudging himself to be the main attraction who was bringing in the crowds;<ref name=W95/> and he claimed what he termed his "expenses" whenever he took part in a first-class match.<ref name=R103/> By the standards of the time, cricket was a lucrative business for the Graces, especially considering that they held [[Amateur status in first-class cricket#Distinction between amateurs and professionals|amateur status]].<ref name=R103/>
The peak of the Graces' involvement was 1873 when W. G. made 16 appearances, which was considerable in terms of the travelling involved and given his commitments to Gloucestershire, MCC and elsewhere. [[James Lillywhite]] was the team secretary at this time, in succession to Willsher, but W. G. and Fred effectively took over. Fred did most of the spadework, hardly ever missing a match and effectively running the team which he captained in W. G.'s absence. Indeed, it was on occasion billed as "G. F. Grace's United South of England XI".<ref>Rae, p.133.</ref>
==USEE matches against the UNEE== When the [[United North of England Eleven]] (UNEE) was founded in 1869, it soon established a regional rivalry with the USEE and the two teams met three times in 1870, the UNEE's first season. The UNEE got off to a flying start when they easily beat the USEE, including the Graces, at [[Lord's]] in July 1870 by an innings and 70 runs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1645.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=USEE v UNEE, Lord's 1870 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> In the next match at [[Bramall Lane]], Sheffield, the UNEE won by an innings and 5 runs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1657.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Bramall Lane 1870 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> The Graces did not play in this game. The teams met again at The Oval in August and this match was drawn, the USEE needing 33 more to win with eight wickets standing and W. G. Grace still in with 51 not out.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1668.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=USEE v UNEE, The Oval 1870 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
The teams did not meet in 1871 and their rivalry was renewed in 1872 when four matches were arranged although the last one at Leeds in September was cancelled.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1790.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Leeds 1872 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> The first match at Bishop's Stortford in June was drawn.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1748.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=USEE v UNEE, Bishop's Stortford 1872 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> In August, the UNEE won by 8 wickets at Hunslet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1777.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Hunslet 1872 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> In September at Northampton, the tide turned and the USEE recorded its first win over the UNEE by 8 wickets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1788.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=USEE v UNEE, Northampton 1872 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
The elevens did not meet in 1873 and there were two matches in 1874 at Todmorden and Wellingborough. At Todmorden in July, the USEE won convincingly by an innings and 30 runs, largely due to a century by [[Henry Charlwood]] and ten wickets taken by W. G. Grace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1906.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Todmorden 1874 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> The USEE won by 9 wickets at Wellingborough in September after the UNEE followed on.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1923.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=USEE v UNEE, Wellingborough 1872 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
There were no matches in 1875 and then the UNEE reasserted itself in 1876 with a win and a draw from two matches. The first at [[Fartown Ground, Huddersfield]] was won by 7 wickets after [[Andrew Greenwood]] scored 111.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/2/2041.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Huddersfield 1876 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref> In the second match at the [[Town Cricket Club Ground]] in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]], the UNEE was saved by an innings of 108 not out by [[Ephraim Lockwood]] but the highlight of the match was W. G. Grace's innings of 126 in a USEE total of only 159.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/2/2052.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=UNEE v USEE, Hull 1876 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
==Other first-class matches== The 1876 match in Hull was the last time the UNEE played the USEE although there was a curious footnote to the series when the USEE played against the official [[North of England cricket team]] on 6 & 7 September 1880. The North's team in this match at Rotherham bore little resemblance to the UNEE but, nevertheless, the official North hammered another nail into the coffin of the unofficial USEE with a 53 run victory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/2/2422.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=North v USEE, Rotherham 1880 |accessdate=5 December 2008}}</ref>
The USEE had earlier played in two other first-class matches. These were in June 1874, when they played [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] in Bradford; and May 1876 when they played the [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven|All-England Eleven]] (AEE) at Lord's. The USEE lost both these matches. Yorkshire beat them by 26 runs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1885.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=Yorkshire v USEE, Bradford 1874 |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> They lost to the AEE by an innings and 84 runs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/2/2004.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=AEE v USEE, Lord's 1876 |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref>
==Odds matches== According to ''CricketArchive'''s database, the USEE played in 217 matches in which they were the travelling team operating on an itinerant basis by taking on local sides that invariably had odds, typically using 22 players against the USEE's eleven. The first of these games took place at Dublin in May 1865 and the USEE fielded a strong team of [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] and [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] professionals, but the Ireland XXII managed a draw.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/99/99607.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=Ireland XXII v USEE XI, Dublin 1865 |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> The last-ever match was at Stroud on 9, 10 & 11 September 1880, just after the match in Hull against the official North. The match against the Stoud XXII was drawn.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/195/195120.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=Stroud XXII v USEE XI, Stroud 1880 |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> Poignantly, it was also the last cricket match ever played by USEE stalwart Fred Grace, who died eleven days later. According to [[Simon Rae]], the United South died with him.<ref>Rae, p.266.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Altham |first=H. S. |authorlink=Harry Altham |title=A History of Cricket, Volume 1 (to 1914) |year=1962 |publisher=George Allen & Unwin |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Birley |first=Derek |authorlink=Derek Birley |title=A Social History of English Cricket |year=1999 |publisher=Aurum |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Bowen |first=Rowland |authorlink=Rowland Bowen |title=Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development |year=1970 |publisher=Eyre & Spottiswoode |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Rae |first=Simon |authorlink=Simon Rae |title=W. G. Grace: A Life |year=1998 |publisher= |isbn=978-0-571-17855-1}} * {{cite book |last=Williams |first=Charles |authorlink=Charles Williams, Baron Williams of Elvel |title=Gentlemen & Players: The Death of Amateurism in Cricket |year=2012 |publisher=Phoenix |isbn=978-0-7538-2927-1}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox handball club | clubname = VKLSE Győr | image = | fullname = Volt Kinizsis Lányok Sportklubja Egyesület | short name = VKLSE | founded = 2000 | ground = [[Magvassy Mihály Sportcsarnok]], [[Győr]] | capacity = 2,800 seats | chairman = Tibor Csomor | manager = Tibor Csomor | league = [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B (Women's handball)|Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B]] | season = 2009–10 | position = Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B – Western Group, 9th | pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= |pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=000000 |body1=E42217 |rightarm1=000000 |shorts1=000000 | pattern_la2= |pattern_b2= |pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=ffffff |body2=ffffff |rightarm2=ffffff |shorts2=ffffff | website = http://vkcsk.hu | colour1 = #E42217 | colour2 = black }} '''Volt Kinizsis Lányok Sportklubja Egyesület''' is a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] women's [[team handball|handball]] club from [[Győr]]. They currently compete in the [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B (Women's handball)|Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B]], the second tier championship in Hungary.
== History == The club was founded in 2000 by the former [[Győri ETO KC|Győri Keksz ETO]] players, who have played on hobby level after their retirement from professional handball. In 2001 they entered the county level championship, which is the fourth tier of Hungarian handball leagues. They dominated through the whole season and gained immediate promotion to [[Nemzeti Bajnokság II (Women's handball)|Nemzeti Bajnokság II]]. After finishing constantly between 3rd and 5th places in the next half decade the breakthrough came in the 2007/08 edition of NB II. By winning 18 league matches beside only one loss and one draw, the Győr-based team found themselves on the top spot at the end of the season and celebrated a further promotion.
Getting ready for a higher level went slowly for VKLSE. Their inaugural season in [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B (Women's handball)|Nemzeti Bajnokság I/B]] ended tristful: with only three wins the team finished second from bottom and escaped from relegation only because the league have been expanded from 11 to 14 teams that year. For the 2009–10 season VKLSE strengthened the squad with experienced players, which resulted some improvement and they captured the 9th position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vkcsk.hu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=62&Itemid=58|title=Bemutatkozás|publisher=VKLSE Győr Official Website|accessdate=22 February 2011|language=Hungarian}}</ref>

'''The West Africa Cricket Council''' was a regional body which organised [[cricket]] teams from [[Gambia]], [[Ghana]], [[Nigeria]], and [[Sierra Leone]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-85127663.html |title=The Empire bats back; Answers to Correspondents |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=26 April 2002 |accessdate=22 December 2012 |via=[[HighBeam]] |subscription=yes}}</ref>
It ceased to exist in 1997 with the formation of the [[African Cricket Association]], which now oversees all cricket administration across the African continent.
The West African Cricket Council organised a unified team called the [[West African cricket team|West African Cricket Team]]. They never managed to qualify for the [[ICC Cricket World Cup]], although competed in the [[ICC Trophy]] on three occasions.
The team was an associate member of the [[International Cricket Council|ICC]] from 1976 until 2003, when the member states of the West African Cricket Council came under the administration of the newly formed [[African Cricket Association]].
